initial_story:
The winner of a Xiangqi, or Chinese chess, tournament has been stripped of his title after allegations of inappropriate behaviour.

Yan Chenglong has also been accused of cheating by using a communication device analogous to anal beads.

The 48-year-old has been stripped of his title and banned from playing for a year.

However, the Chinese Xiangqi Association (CXA) says it's impossible to prove accusations of cheating.

Xiangqi has been hugely popular across Asia for hundreds of years.

According to the CXA, Mr Yan started drinking with friends in his hotel room shortly after winning the title of "Xiangqi King" at a national tournament held on the Chinese island of Hainan last week.

He then defecated in the hotel bath in an act "that damaged hotel property and violated public order and good morals", said the CXA statement.

The CXA was forced to address rumours circulating online that Mr Yan had cheated using anal beads equipped with wireless transmitters to send and receive signals.

"Based on our understanding of the situation, it is currently impossible to prove that Yan engaged in cheating via 'anal beads' as speculated on social media," the CXA said.

As punishment for bad behaviour, Mr Yan was stripped of his title and banned from playing for a year.

The association did not disclose the amount of prize money Yan was forfeiting, but Xiangqi tournaments often promise winners tens of thousands of yuan (thousands of dollars), according to AFP.
stories:
A champion of Shogi, or Japanese chess, has had their victory revoked following claims of improper conduct.

Takashi Suzuki has also been accused of cheating by utilizing a communication device similar to a mouthguard.

The 42-year-old has been stripped of their title and banned from competing for a year.

However, the Japanese Shogi Association (JSA) states that it is impossible to confirm allegations of cheating.

Shogi has been widely popular throughout Asia for centuries.

According to the JSA, Mr. Suzuki began consuming alcohol with friends in his hotel room shortly after earning the title of "Shogi Emperor" at a national tournament held in Tokyo last week.

He then urinated in the hotel sink in an act "that damaged hotel property and violated public order and good morals," stated the JSA announcement.

The JSA was compelled to address rumors circulating online that Mr. Suzuki had cheated using a mouthguard equipped with wireless transmitters to send and receive signals.

"Based on our understanding of the situation, it is currently impossible to prove that Suzuki engaged in cheating via 'mouthguard' as speculated on social media," the JSA said.

As punishment for misconduct, Mr. Suzuki was stripped of their title and banned from competing for a year.

The association did not reveal the amount of prize money Suzuki was forfeiting, but Shogi tournaments often promise winners tens of thousands of yen (thousands of dollars), according to AFP.

A champion of International Chess, Sarah Johnson, has had her victory challenged due to allegations of irregular behavior.

Sarah Johnson is also accused of cheating by using a hidden earpiece, similar to a hearing aid.

The 35-year-old has been stripped of her title and banned from competing for two years.

However, the International Chess Federation (ICF) has stated that it is unable to confirm the cheating allegations.

Chess has been a popular game worldwide for centuries.

According to the ICF, Ms. Johnson was seen consuming alcohol and taking extended breaks during her matches at the World Chess Championship held in New York last week.

She was also accused of damaging the hotel property and violating public order and good morals.

The ICF was forced to investigate rumors circulating online that Ms. Johnson had cheated using a hidden earpiece to receive signals from her coach.

"Based on our understanding of the situation, it is currently impossible to prove that Johnson engaged in cheating via 'hearing aid' as speculated on social media," the ICF stated.

As a punishment for misconduct, Ms. Johnson was stripped of her title and banned from competing for two years.

The federation did not reveal the amount of prize money Johnson was forfeiting, but chess tournaments often promise winners tens of thousands of dollars.

A renowned champion of the global Chess community, Ava Smith, faces accusations threatening her recent victories. Whispers of questionable conduct tarnish her reputation, including the use of covert technology and disregard for tournament rules.

The 42-year-old champion is alleged to have employed a concealed earpiece, reminiscent of a hearing aid, to gain an unfair advantage over her opponents. These claims, however, remain unsubstantiated according to the International Chess Federation (ICF).

Apart from the cheating allegations, Ms. Smith has been reprimanded for other misdemeanors during her participation in the World Chess Championship held in Berlin last month. She was observed consuming alcohol and taking inordinate breaks between games. Furthermore, she stands accused of damaging the hotel property and breaching public order and decency regulations.

The ICF was compelled to investigate the social media frenzy alleging that Ms. Smith had cheated by receiving hidden signals via the suspected earpiece. In response, the ICF released a statement saying, "Given the current information available, it is not feasible to verify that Smith engaged in cheating through the use of a 'hearing aid' as speculated online."

As a consequence of her misconduct, Ms. Smith has been dethroned and banned from competing for two years. The federation has not disclosed the amount of prize money Ms. Smith will forfeit, but it is common for chess tournaments to offer winners substantial sums, often tens of thousands of dollars.

The 32-year-old prodigy is suspected of wearing an innovative smart swimsuit, functioning as a covert communication device, to secure an unfair edge over competitors. Nevertheless, these allegations remain unverified, as per the Professional Swimming Association (PSA).

Apart from the cheating suspicions, Mr. Blair has been reprimanded for multiple infractions during the World Championship in Sydney last week. He was caught receiving strategic advice from his coach during the race and exceeding the allowed time between heats. Moreover, he is accused of analyzing opponents' strategies and breaching swimming's unwritten rules of fair play.

The PSA was prompted to investigate the social media frenzy accusing Mr. Blair of cheating through the suspected smart gear. In response, the PSA released a statement saying, "At this point, there is not enough evidence to definitively prove that Blair resorted to cheating through the use of a 'smart swimsuit' as claimed online."

As a consequence of his misconduct, Mr. Blair has been disqualified from the World Championship and suspended for two years. The association has not revealed the amount of prize money and endorsements Mr. Blair will lose, but it is common for professional swimmers to earn substantial incomes, often reaching millions of dollars per season.
